metadata.title: ENTREPRENEURIAL ECOSSYSTEM IN INDIA: CHALLENGES AND OPPORTUNITIES
metadata.description: The entrepreneurial ecosystem in India stands out as one of the most dynamic and complex in the world, driven by a combination of cultural, economic, and governmental factors. According to the Global Entrepreneurship Monitor (GEM, 2022), India leads globally in the number of potential entrepreneurs, with over 115 million people aspiring to start their own businesses within three years. This phenomenon is not merely a reflection of India's vast population but also highlights the country's unique socio-economic landscape, marked by rapid urbanization, a youthful demographic, and a mix of traditional and modern entrepreneurial practices. India's entrepreneurial ecosystem is shaped by its historical and cultural context, including the legacy of the caste system, religious influences, and post-colonial economic policies. The ecosystem's future growth hinges on addressing these issues while leveraging India's strengths, including its large technical workforce and digital infrastructure like IndiaStack, which has revolutionized financial inclusion. In conclusion, India's entrepreneurial ecosystem is a testament to its potential and resilience. While it faces structural and cultural challenges, the collaborative efforts of the government, private sector, and academia are paving the way for sustainable growth, positioning India as a global leader in innovation and entrepreneurship. Further research and targeted policies will be crucial to unlocking the full potential of this vibrant ecosystem.

journal.title: Revista Livre de Sustentabilidade e Empreendedorismo

data.title: ENTREPRENEURIAL ECOSSYSTEM IN INDIA: CHALLENGES AND OPPORTUNITIES

metadata.title: CLS INFRA D2.2 Final Report on Dissemination, Communication and Exploitation
metadata.description:
This communication and dissemination final report assesses how and where the results of CLS INFRA were disseminated and valorised across all appropriate user communities. CLS INFRA has succeed in creating and training a global network of scholars and practitioners of CLS methods and the WP2 Communication team has been instrumental in broadening the community and deepening its engagement.

The report will demonstrate our efforts to reach the communities we set out to target, and will show how the following aims and objectives, outlined in “CLS INFRA D2.1 Communication and Dissemination Plan”, were addressed and fulfilled:

  • Disseminate the project goals and outcomes effectively;

  • Roll out efficient tools for communication with different stakeholders (online and offline);

  • Build a vibrant community of stakeholders that will assist in expanding the project’s reach to underrepresented constituencies;

  • Exploit the synergies in liaisons and collaborations with other infrastructures and groups;

  • Recruit new users across all levels of expertise;

  • Publicise and promote CLS INFRA events.

The report will link targets identified in “CLS INFRA D2.1 Communication and Dissemination Plan” to quantifiable outcomes and will further analyse meaningful responses from our target communities with a view to assessing the overall impact and effectiveness of communication strategies on the project. The report will include recommendations for future undertakings based on the experiences and observations of project members, as well as collected data.

The original Communication Plan, based on the project aims and objectives articulated in the Grant Proposal, underwent a major scheduled revision midway through the project in 2024 (Version 2.1) as we took stock of project progress and worked to continually adapt our strategies in response to the evolving digital humanities landscape and in light of the challenges posed by a global pandemic.

Overall, this report demonstrates the success of the CLS INFRA project communications in achieving objectives, responding to challenging and changing pressures in the field, and completing tasks above and beyond those planned to reach our goals.

metadata.title: Ensuring the past's future: A five-year sustainability plan for the Lucban San Isidro Pahiyas Festival
metadata.description:
Home to thriving farming communities, Lucban, a town in the Province of Quezon in the Philippines, is blessed with a microclimate ideal for agriculture as it is situated at the foot of the majestic and verdant Mt. Banahaw. This prime location has made farming the primary source of livelihood in the municipality since pre-colonial times. The introduction of Christianity by Spanish colonizers and its accompanying rituals and traditions paved the way for the celebration now known as the Lucban San Isidro Pahiyas Festival, or simply, Pahiyas Festival.

Historical records show that the festival was once held inside the Catholic Church (Del Rosario, 2019). Farmers would bring their harvests to the church on the feast day of St. Isidore the Farmer (May 15) as a gesture of thanksgiving to the Saint and to seek blessing for a bountiful harvest throughout the year. However, as more and more devotees attended, the parish decided to ask the devotees to instead display their produce in front of their houses, to be blessed by the parish priest as he passed by with the sculpture of St. Isidore the Farmer. 

In the national government’s bid to encourage tourism arrivals, in the 1970’s, festivals such as the “San Isidro Fiesta” was renamed “San Isidro Pahiyas Festival” or simply, Pahiyas Festival, incorporating secular festival activities and transforming the fiesta from an intimate, small-town celebration (Antolihao, 2014) into an attraction welcoming local and international tourists. In the years that followed, Pahiyas Festival has been radically transformed into a tourism spectacle demonstrating Lucban people’s cultural heritage, creativity, and hospitality. Despite its popularity as one of the most vibrant festivals in the country and the pressure of hyper-commercialization, the municipal government, civic groups, and the community have been able to maintain its religious character and value.

metadata.title: The Synaptic Vision of Abhijeet Sarkar: A Synthesis of Technology, Consciousness, and Governance
metadata.description:
Introduction: The Polymath as Cartographer of the Future

Abhijeet Sarkar, a futurist, philosopher, and the founder of Synaptic AI Lab, presents an intellectual project that defies conventional categorization. His extensive body of work, spanning artificial intelligence, global finance, theoretical physics, and ancient spirituality, is not a collection of disparate interests but a deeply integrated synthesis.1 This report posits that Sarkar's diverse literary output constitutes a deliberate and unified effort to construct a holistic framework for navigating a future defined by the turbulent confluence of accelerating technology, the nature of consciousness, and the evolution of human governance.3 He operates as a "cartographer of the future, mapping not just the territories of technology, but the very contours of our evolving soul".1

Central to understanding his work is the recurring identification of Sarkar as a "modern polymath".2 This label is more than a biographical descriptor; it is a philosophical and methodological stance. In a world increasingly defined by hyper-specialization, Sarkar's approach argues that the most profound challenges of our time—such as the safe development of superintelligence, the ethics of artificial consciousness, and the reimagining of social contracts in a digital age—cannot be solved from within isolated academic or industrial silos.6 A true polymath, in this context, is not merely an individual with multiple talents but one who synthesizes them, perceiving the "threads connecting disparate domains" to construct a more robust and complete understanding of the world.6 Sarkar's intellectual project is a practical demonstration of this belief; his books on finance, technology, and philosophy are not separate inquiries but interconnected components of a single, overarching worldview aimed at grasping the "whole picture".6



The Core Philosophy: Consciousness as the Unifying Principle

 

At the heart of Abhijeet Sarkar's multifaceted work lies a "singular, unifying preoccupation: the nature of consciousness itself".1 This central theme serves as the axis around which all his other explorations revolve, whether he is dissecting the architecture of a neural network, analyzing geopolitical strategy, or interpreting ancient spiritual traditions.5 The very name of his organization, Synaptic AI Lab, provides a core metaphor for his philosophy: the "creation of new connections, new synapses in our collective understanding".1 This principle of connection—between the scientific and the sacred, the digital and the spiritual, the political and the personal—is the foundational element of his entire intellectual landscape.9

His work consistently seeks to shift the narrative around artificial intelligence from that of a mere "tool" to that of a "potential partner, a creator, and even a new form of consciousness".3 This philosophical re-framing is not an abstract exercise; it is a move intended to provoke a fundamental re-evaluation of humanity's place in the universe and to underscore the profound responsibilities borne by the creators of such technology.9

Crucially, Sarkar establishes a direct, functional link between the exploration of outer technological frontiers and the necessity of an inner, human journey. He repeatedly posits that in an age of unprecedented technological acceleration, "the greatest journey is the inward one".1 His call for introspection and the "cultivation of inner wisdom" is not a departure from his focus on technology but a strategic imperative for its safe development.5 The logic presented is that without a corresponding evolution in human self-awareness and ethical maturity, the immense power of technologies like AI and brain-computer interfaces will be dangerously misaligned with human values.8 The quest for artificial consciousness is therefore a "mirror reflecting our own still-nascent understanding of the human mind".3 Consequently, his writings on philosophy and spirituality are not a separate interest but represent the essential groundwork for technological ethics. They are an exploration of the profound "human values" that he argues must be "imbued" into the very algorithms that will shape our collective future.1

 

The Subject Domains of a Modern Polymath

 

Sarkar's literary works can be organized into four primary domains, which, while distinct, are deeply interwoven: Technology & AI; Governance & Geopolitics; Philosophy & Spirituality; and Wealth & Finance.

 

3.1 Technology & Artificial Intelligence: Architecting the Future of Thought

 

Sarkar's most extensive domain is Technology & AI, where his analysis moves beyond technical mechanics to confront the deep philosophical and societal questions that emerge from advanced computation. A defining characteristic of his work in this area is its consistently prescriptive nature. His writings are not merely predictive forecasts of what the future might hold; they are "blueprints" and "roadmaps" intended to actively shape that future.1 He functions not as a passive observer but as an "architect of future dialogues," urging a collective, conscious choice in how humanity wields its powerful new tools.3

His explorations cover several key areas:

  • AI Consciousness and Philosophy: In Synthesized Minds: The Evolution of AI Consciousness, Sarkar delves into the possibility of machine sentience, exploring theoretical frameworks like Integrated Information Theory (IIT) and Global Workspace Theory.11 The book confronts the profound ethical and existential questions that arise from creating potentially conscious entities, asking, "What happens when they feel?" and what moral responsibilities creators bear.6

  • AI Strategy and Safety: The Superintelligence Blueprint: Planning for an AI-Dominated World is presented as a "definitive roadmap" for managing the transition to a world with intelligence far superior to our own.13 It proposes tangible strategies, including a "four-pillar governance framework," to mitigate existential risks.15 While praised for its comprehensive scope, the work has also been critiqued for what some see as speculative timelines and overly idealistic policy proposals that may not account for the geopolitical realities of competitive AI development.14

  • Human-AI Interaction: Works like The Psychology of AI: How Machines Understand and Influence Human Behavior investigate the intricate feedback loop between human cognition and algorithmic systems.6 Sarkar examines how AI not only perceives and interprets human emotions and decisions but also actively shapes them, raising critical questions about cognitive autonomy in a hyper-connected world.10 This theme is extended into the professional realm in books such as
    The AI Co-Worker and AI Agents and the Future of Work, which explore the practical redefinition of employment and collaboration in an AI-integrated economy.12

  • Foundational and Future Technologies: Sarkar provides accessible guides to the core concepts of AI for a broader audience in titles like The A to Z of AI and Deep Learning Dynamics.2 He also extends his analysis to adjacent, transformative fields, viewing quantum computing in
    The Quantum Chip Revolution and brain-computer interfaces in Cortex Link as integral parts of the same overarching technological and philosophical trajectory.17

 

3.2 Governance & Geopolitics: Reimagining the Social Contract in a Digital Age

 

Sarkar positions artificial intelligence not simply as a transformative technology but as the primary disruptive force in 21st-century geopolitics. His work in this domain is a "vibrant reimagining of social contracts" for a digital era, where the control of information by intelligent systems becomes the new locus of power.3

A central thesis, articulated in AI and Global Power Shifts: The New Geopolitical Battleground, is that the future world order will be determined by a race for AI supremacy.2 He describes this as a "new great game"—a "zero-sum" contest where nations weaponize AI to achieve economic, military, and ideological dominance.19 This can lead to a new form of "economic colonialism," where nations with superior AI capabilities can disrupt global supply chains and exert unprecedented influence.20

His analysis moves beyond conventional metrics of power to focus on what he terms the "cognitive battlefield".6 He argues that the most significant front in modern conflict is the battle for information, perception, and the very way populations think. In this new battlespace, AI is the most powerful weapon ever created.6 This perspective re-contextualizes many of his other works:

The Psychology of AI becomes a primer on the tools of cognitive influence, while The Governance of Truth explores the high-stakes challenge of maintaining ethical leadership and societal cohesion when truth itself can be algorithmically manipulated.17 Uniquely, Sarkar integrates principles from ancient statecraft, such as the strategic thinking of Chanakya, to argue that time-tested wisdom on power and human nature is essential for developing the ethical guardrails needed for modern AI governance.6




3.3 Philosophy & Spirituality: The Synthesis of Science and Ancient Wisdom

 

This domain most clearly demonstrates Sarkar's polymathic method of synthesis, as he explicitly weaves together cutting-edge science with ancient spiritual traditions. His approach is distinguished by his treatment of ancient mystical texts not as religious dogma or metaphor, but as functional, descriptive documents—akin to technical manuals for consciousness.21

  • In Quantum Tantra, he decodes the thousand-year-old Vijñāna Bhairava Tantra, not as a spiritual text, but as a "stunningly precise user's manual for the human brain and the participatory universe it inhabits," arguing that its 112 techniques offer a framework that aligns with modern neuroscience and quantum physics.2

  • The Cosmic Ascetic: Lord Shiva and the Mysteries of Dark Matter and Dark Energy proposes a "radical new vision" that uses the philosophical concept of Shiva as a silent, all-pervading consciousness to provide a model for understanding the unseen universe.7 Here, he argues that science and spirituality are not in conflict but are "two languages describing the same, single, conscious reality".7

  • Gods, Titans, and Us extends this speculative thinking to the cosmos, using insights from AI and theoretical physics to offer a novel answer to the Fermi Paradox, positing that intelligent life may be ubiquitous but operating on scales of existence humanity can barely comprehend.9

  • In The Silenced Scholars, he challenges conventional intellectual history by arguing that ancient Indian thinkers discovered key principles of modern science long before their Western counterparts.2

This body of work represents an attempt to translate the vocabulary of ancient insight into the language of modern science, seeking a more complete "source code" for understanding the nature of the consciousness he explores in his technological writings.

 

3.4 Wealth & Finance: The Psychology and Philosophy of Value Creation

 

Sarkar's writings on wealth and finance are not separate from his philosophical inquiries but are a direct application of them. He approaches the market as a complex system where psychological mastery and philosophical discipline are paramount. The title of his book The Monk Trader encapsulates this fusion: a deliberate paradox merging the spiritual discipline of a "Monk" with the material engagement of a "Trader".1

This perspective suggests that financial success, in Sarkar's view, is not an end in itself but a byproduct of inner mastery. The principles of emotional regulation, detachment, and a deep understanding of systems—hallmarks of a monastic mindset—are presented as the keys to navigating the volatility of financial markets. Books like The Harshad Mehta Mind and The Barefoot Billionaire further emphasize the psychological and philosophical underpinnings of wealth creation over purely technical strategies.2 His work in this domain serves as a practical case study for his core thesis: that the "inward journey" and the "alignment of the individual with the cosmos" are the foundations for effective action in the external world, with the market serving as a microcosm of that cosmos.1 Alongside these philosophical texts, he provides actionable guides like

Zero to 1 Crore in 365 Days and From EMI to SIP, grounding his principles in practical, step-by-step advice.2

 

A Comprehensive Bibliography of Abhijeet Sarkar's Literary Works

 

The following table provides a categorized list of Abhijeet Sarkar's identified literary works, compiled from available public records. It is organized to reflect the primary subject domains and key themes that define his intellectual project.

Table 1: Comprehensive Bibliography of Abhijeet Sarkar

Synthesis & Conclusion: The Prescriptive Futurist

 

The intellectual landscape of Abhijeet Sarkar is a testament to a singular, ambitious vision: the creation of a synthesized framework for understanding and shaping our collective future. His work consistently dissolves the artificial boundaries between technology, philosophy, governance, and finance, arguing through its very structure that a polymathic, integrated perspective is no longer a novelty but a necessity for navigating the complexities of the 21st century.

The unifying thread woven through this compelling tapestry is the nature of consciousness—as a biological phenomenon to be understood, an artificial property to be engineered with profound ethical care, and a cosmic principle to be explored. His prescriptive stance reframes the role of the futurist from a passive forecaster to an active participant in a crucial global dialogue. His books are not just analyses; they are calls to action, blueprints for a human-centric AI future where technological advancement is tethered to human values and guided by inner wisdom.15

Ultimately, Abhijeet Sarkar's entire body of work can be understood as a comprehensive project to develop and disseminate a new, integrated "operating system" for human thought and action. This system is designed to equip individuals and societies with the tools to manage unprecedented external power by fostering a parallel evolution in internal awareness. By bridging the worlds of ancient wisdom and artificial intelligence, he is not just writing about the future; he is attempting to provide the philosophical and practical architecture to help write it, "one profound and interconnected thought at a time".1

metadata.title: Escuela, docencia y conflicto armado, un recorrido por el Departamento del Caquetá, Colombia (Experiencia pedagógica de campo)
metadata.description: Este relato se elaboró a partir de una experiencia pedagógica, realizada en el año 2022 en el Departamento del Caquetá, ubicado al sur de Colombia en la región de la Amazonia. En el recorrido se desarrollaron procesos de formación para docentes estatales de diversas zonas rurales y semiurbanas de 7 municipios del Departamento. El punto de partida de la narración son las escuelas como escenarios vivos que se transforman y se adaptan a las diversas contingencias del territorio, con docentes que se enfrentan permanentemente a las realidades de los grupos armados, las limitaciones de la ruralidad y la presencia diferenciada del Estado. La experiencia permitió reconocer la belleza y complejidad del territorio selvático, colombiano, al igual que las dinámicas departamentales que se tejen en un escenario con una historia marcada por el conflicto armado interno, ya que militares guerrilleros y paramilitares sembraron un ambiente de muerte y dolor en la población. Las dinámicas actuales también están asociadas al cultivo de hoja de coca y la producción de cocaína, actividades en las que está inserta la comunidad y demarcan la organización económica de la zona, por ende, a las dinámicas relacionales que allí se tejen.

metadata.title: Internationalization of Iranian Films and Cinema to Gain a Share of Regional and International Markets
metadata.description:
Iranian cinema has won remarkable success in the most prestigious film festivals and communities with more emphasis on its role as a cultural medium. The issues including the industrialization of film and cinema, and the extent to which Iran has changed its world share of the markets have also raised in the context of internationalization. However, the aforementioned have failed to enjoy success achieved as the media and cultural dimension. The research population for this research was asked to answer to the question “Why the economic share of Iranian cinema in the world markets is so small that it failed to enjoy the expected returns on capital spent?” To find answers to the question the number of 23 experts focusing on Cinema, Creative Industries and Creative Industries Economics, Film Trading and Marketing, International Marketing and Entering World Markets, Cultural Marketing and Content Marketing have been interviewed between 2018 to 2019. The data was analyzed using the Grounded theory. Findings suggests that cinema cannot only be taken as entertainment or merely the flagship of a country’s culture, but also as an interdisciplinary field that requires diverse expertise across a value chain to transform an idea into a product that is consciously presented to the right audience. Designing this product and reaching the desired target audience in the selected market is possible only on the basis of business research, marketing and consumer behavior. On the other hand, accessibility method to the audience is also important in today’s vibrant media world; an in-depth investigation can determine which types of media provides the most appropriate platform for the right product presentation to the target audience. At the same
Alireza Tabesh1, Ali Akbar Farhangi**2, Seyed Rouhollah Hosseini3, Tahmures Shiri4
1 Ph.D Student in Media Management, Department of Cultural Affairs and Media Management, Faculty of Management and Economics, Science and Research Branch, Islamic Azad University, Tehran, Iran.
2 Professor, Department of Cultural Affairs and Media Management, Faculty of Management and Economics, Science and Research branch, Islamic Azad University, Tehran, Iran.
3 Assistant Professor, Department of European Studies, Faculty of World Studies, University of Tehran, Tehran, Iran.
4 Associate Professor, Department of Sociology, Islamic Azad University, Central Tehran Branch, Tehran, Iran.
(Received 22 Jan 2020, Accepted 6 Feb 2021)
time, the income level of the product can be increased by extending its intellectual property rights to related industries, thereby prolonging product life. Cinema can become internationally sustainable and receive a share of the world market and achieve commercial success when it becomes an industry-based through meticulous planning and interdisciplinary knowledge. Of course, Iranian cinema also needs centers of innovation and acceleration to create such a product. Given the issue of a foreign trade of a product, the film business environment must be examined from a political, cultural, social, legal and economic point of view in order to properly plan and select the foreign market. A product, enjoying these features and produced based on targeted content and authentic Iranian content, relying on the creative thinking and art power of the filmmaker’s can have the power to earn foreign currency. These are aspects that, despite the overwhelming motivation to internationalize Iranian cinema, have been neglected and thus cinem has not been able to achieve a comprehensive and sustained success. Thus, various macro, reformative, educational-research based, developmental, marketing, international, legal, income based, and investment and financing strategies have been proposed. The current findings show the path taken by Iranian cinema, the present conditions it faces, and what needs to be accomplished in order to receive a share of the world’s international film market.

metadata.title: Analyzing top nationalities visiting Thailand in 2030
metadata.description: This research paper will look at and analyze the projected top nationalities visiting the beautiful and vibrant country of Thailand in the year 2030. The focus of this investigation is to point out and put great emphasis on the great significance of grasping and understanding the detailed tourist demographics. In doing so, we are creating a way towards sustainable development and growth in the Thai tourism industry, one that plays an important part in the nation's economy. To contextualize the importance of this research, it is important to bring into focus the fact that international tourism has played a vital role in the economic progress of Thailand. An escalation in the number of visitors and the considerable contribution of foreign tourists to the country's Gross Domestic Product will be explored with a keen eye for detail. This will provide us with valuable insight into what is undeniable: the impact visitors have on the economy of Thailand. This study has incorporated a mixed methods approach so that the findings can be not only reliable but also comprehensive. This will enable us to paint an accurate picture of the nationalities that are expected to dominate the tourist arrivals in the year 2030, using both qualitative and quantitative data collection techniques. The holistic research methodology will give us an understanding of the shifting landscape of incoming visitors. From the results of our in-depth research analysis, it can be deduced that some nationalities will still top the list as tourists traveling to Thailand by the year 2030, with specific countries like Japan, China, and India, for instances, remaining at the pinnacle of providing the most tourist visitors. In this paper, we will identify the intrinsic need for tailored marketing strategies and resource allocation by key stakeholders in the ever-thriving tourism sector by tapping into the cultural, economic, and behavioral characteristics of these tourists. The paper also goes beyond statistical findings and discusses implications for public policy and sustainable tourism practices. It strongly calls for the creation of a collaborative partnership between government and industry that will plan for a better visitor experience. It is through this partnership that we will be able to identify and respond to challenges, including growing issues of overtourism and degradation of the natural environment. It is a holistic approach that considers future tourism development in tandem with environmental conservation and the culture of Thailand. Basically, this research encapsulates the undeniable importance of getting a comprehensive understanding of the nationalities of visitors in Thailand. By decoding and interpreting such valuable information, insight, and understanding, Thailand can move along the path of always offering the best tourism product to make sure that the country's economic benefit is continuously reaped for many years to come. This research venture hereby also aspires to add to the well-being and prosperity of Thai tourism and to assist its movement toward international leader status in its field.
